Evolutionary and ecological mechanisms determining the co-existence of closely related species assemblage on the mountains of Himalayas
Project
The flora of China is extremely diverse with more than 30,000 species of angiosperms (Wu et al. 2013). The mountains of southwest China are regarded as one of global hotspots of biodiversity with the highest diversity of species and endemism of all temperate floras (Myers et al. 2000). In this region, some speciose genera form extensive species assemblages in fine scale habitats (sub-alpine and alpine meadows) but without large scale range divergence. As an example, Pedicularis with more than 300 species (75% of them are endemic) is distributed on the mountain of Himalayas, they occur in sympatric populations, and also flower synchronously and share same bumblebee pollinators. Other such genera include Primula, Gentiana, Rhododendron et al. The floral diversity of high elevation mountains of this region is strongly shaped by generalist bee species, such as Chinese native honeybee Apis cerana and bumblebees (Ren et al. 2014; Zhao et al. 2016). This region also harbours the half of global species of bumblebees (Williams et al. 2009). In this project, we use multiple approaches including pollination ecology, reproductive isolation, genetics, DNA barcoding and ecological network to understand the evolution and ecology aspects of the co-existence of these closely related species assemblages. We ask the question how do closely related species coexist in the same community. Specifically, we address 1) Reproductive isolation of closely related species under same pollination niche (syndrome); 2)The relative contribution of pre- and post-pollination barriers on the total isolation; 3) We use network approach to test the spatial and temporal divergence of pollination niche along the elevation gradients.
